bg_logon_tip.message: If U no long need inspecting webrequest, just disable it.

pop_google_down.message: Sorry, but I can't access Google api.

opt_no_rules.message: You haven't added any rules yet.

opt_deldlg_content.message: You've chosed xx rule(s), are you sure to delete them all?

opt_ph_host.message: required, just paste a url here

opt_ph_testurl.message: paste a real url to test your rule

opt_ph_newurl.message: a url template to generate the new url, like http://abc.us/m/{sub}/{newsid}

opt_ph_urlmatch.message: a url pattern to match, like {sub}.abc.com/news/{newsid}.html

opt_path_rule_tip.message:
The path should obey the following rules(please ommit the prefix /):
  • you give a specific path, likepath,path?num=1
  • wildcard* is also available, like
    • *(aka any path, including empty path)
    • path*(all path start with path)
    • path*.jsp(start with path and end with .jsp)
    • *kwd*(path contains kwd)
    • path?*(all query request to path)
    • path?num=*(all query request to path, and num is the first query parameter, NOTICE: path?ps=23&num=23 won't be matched)

opt_host_rule_tip.message:
The domain should obey the following rules:
  • you give a specific domain, likewww.abc.com
  • IP address is ok too, like8.8.8.8
  • wildcard * can be used to match any subdomains, but only available in domains under second-level domain. so *.abc.com and *.api.abc.com are valid. but *.com and *.netare invalid.

opt_custom_matchrule_tip.message:
The match-url should obey the following rules:
  • A URL must specify its second-level domain, {fld}.com is invalid
  • {kwd}can be used to name the url part that you'd like to focus, and you can use them in redirect-url. like {name}.abc.com
  • {*kwd}can be used to match anything in the end of the path,query string won't be matched.
  • {kwd} can also be used to name the values in query string.
  • the extension has predefined several names, you should not defined them again:
    • umeans URL itself
    • prepresents protocol, like http,https
    • hmeans URL's domain, like g.cn, uk.abc.com
    • mmeans second-level domain, for g.cn/search it's g.cn. and for uk.abc.com/news/, it's abc.com
    • rmeans path(without prefix/), like search, news/998.html
    • qmeans query string(without prefix?), like newwindow=1&safe=2

opt_custom_redirectrule_tip.message:
The redirect-url should obey the following rules:
  • the URL's should has its protocol, you can use http,https, and the predefined {p}
  • names defined in match-url can be used, bracket them with {}
  • and so is the predefined names:
    • umeans URL itself
    • prepresents protocol, like http,https
    • hmeans URL's domain, like g.cn, uk.abc.com
    • mmeans second-level domain, for g.cn/search* it's g.cn. and for uk.abc.com/news/*, it's abc.com
    • rmeans path(without prefix/), like search, news/998.html
    • qmeans query string(without prefix?), like newwindow=1&safe=2

opt_custom_demotip.message: Custom URL is a new feature, I just added a rule to demonstrate it: this rule can redirect your page to Google search results when searching via Baidu automatically. To see how it works, you may enable this feature, then searching on Baidu(http://www.baidu.com) with any keywords and you will see something magic. Please make sure you can get access to Google, or you may be in China:)

opt_help_desc.message: There is something U need to know before using

opt_help_content.message:
About the Extension

This extension is my amateur work. At the very beginning, I just need a tool can monitor some rogue script's requests in browser. Chrome's devtools can only inspect specific Tab's requests which doesn't meet my requirements, so there is this extension (Log function can do this). In order to increase its availability, I added features Block (block sites), HTTPS (force https connection), hotlinking (view hotlinking images) and QRCode ( two-dimensional code). And later with the user's feedback, the killer feature custom (custom URL) was added. This extension is open source. If you have any questions in use, please send me an e-mail feedback.

Basics

Before using, you need to know some basic concepts of URL, URL is used to locate a resource, such as a Web page, a picture, a document. All rules used in this extension are to match some certain URLs. A URL contains four parts: protocol, host name ( domain name or IP), path and optional query string. You can get the detailed description via Wikipedia. I will show you the brief introduction.

Protocol: http https ftp etc. always separate from other parts by :// or :

Host name: aka server address, it could be a domain name(such as abc.com), or an IP address (such as 8.8.8.8). Domain name .com .net .uk are top-level domain name, google.com is a second-level domain , and google.co.uk is a third-level domain. All matching rules must specify the second-level domain, to avoid overly broad rules affect your normal use of the browser, which means that the rules like *.com can not be added, but *.google.com and google.com are ok. About port: the host name can specify a port number, but Chrome does not need it, Chrome will match all ports of the host name.

Path: From the first /, to the first ? (if no ? then until the end). for http://www.hailoverman.com/flowstate?ref=producthunt, its path is /flowstate; for https: //google.com/ is /

Query string: started with a ? until the end. each set of parameters separated by a &, a parameter's name and value separated by =. For http://www.hailoverman.com/flowstate?ref =producthunt, the query string is?ref=producthunt. As query string is optional, URL https://www.google.com/'s query string is empty.

Custom URL

When surfing the Web, you may encounter such a situation: when a website is inaccessible, but its mirror sites is available, so each time you access this site from other sites, you have to modify the URL to view the content; some URL will redirect many times before reaching the real site, redirecting is slow, and once error, you'll never get the target page. With this feature, everything can be done automatically.

This feature requires you declare two rules: matching-rule and redirecting-rule.

Matching-rule

To tell the extension which rule need to be transformed.

You can also use {kwd} or {*kwd} in a rule to name the sections you care, you can use them in the redirecting-rule to assemble the target URL. {kwd} can not match content that contains /, that is, when match the contents in path, it only only gets string between /; {*kwd} can only be used to match the contents of the path, it will match to the end of the path, and can be used only once. Here are some examples:

  • The rule *://{sub}.abc.com/{cat} can match URLs with protocol https or http and its second-level domain is abc.com. The variable sub can capture abc.com's subdomainï¼Œcat can get the first folder name in path. So , for URL http://www.abc.com/news/ax82e3-20140917.html, sub is www, cat is news.
  • The rule http://www.abc.com/news/{id}-{date}.html and rule http://www.abc.com/news/{*rest} both can match all pages under http://www.abc.com/news/, but the value of the variables are different. For example, for URL http://www.abc.com/news/ax82e3-20140917.html , id is ax82e3, date is 20140917, and rest is ax82e3-20140917.html
  • Typically the query string also contains some useful information, you can also use {kwd} to extract. The order of the parameters in query string is not fixed, you just need to claim what you need in the rule. For example, rule https://www.google.com.hk/search?q={kwd} can extract the keyword searched in Google.

Predefined variables

The extension has predefined several variables, you should not defined them again:

  • u means URL itself
  • p represents protocol, like http,https
  • h means URL's domain, like g.cn, uk.abc.com
  • m means second-level domain, for g.cn/search it's g.cn. and for uk.abc.com/news/, it's abc.com
  • r means path(without prefix / ), like search, news/998.html
  • q means query string(without prefix ? ), like newwindow=1&safe=2

redirecting-rule

To tell extension how to build the target URL. You can use your own custom or predefined variables in the redirecting-rule, use with the form {kwd} (no matter whether it's defined in {*kwd} or not), you do not need concerned about translation(URLencode) of the value of these variables, the extension will do it automatically. After both rules are added, you need to test them with a real URL, the test result, aka target URL, must be a valid URL, otherwise it will not be added.

Here are some examples:

  • redirect Baidu search to Google search

    matching-rule: https://www.baidu.com/s?wd={kwd}

    redirecting-rule: https://www.google.com.hk/search?q={kwd}

  • Stop Google search results from redirecting

    matching-rule: https://www.google.com/url?url={url}

    redirecting-rule: {url}

  • visit the nearest mirror site of PHP to improve your access speed

    matching-rule: http://php.net/manual/{*rest}

    redirecting-rule: http://nl1.php.net/manual/{rest}?{q}

Block

You can add patterns to block certain websites, specific images or scripts. Of course, it can be used to block ads, but I do not recommend doing this, this extension does not aim at blocking ads, you can install Adblock to do this.

HTTPS

If a website supports HTTPS, you can add its domain as a rule, then all requests to this site will go through HTTPS. For example, wordpress.com supports HTTPS, then after adding *.wordpress.com as a rule, all blogs including blogs' pictures on wordpress.com will be connected via HTTPS.

Hotlinking

You may have seen many fake pictures because of anti-hotlinking. For now, just right click the picture and click copy image URL, then paste it into the domain input box (clear the path input box so this rule will apply to all pictures under this domain). After this, you can see the original pictures.

Log

Inspect network requests' details including request header (header) and content (body). See the figure below.

Tipsï¼Œby following these steps ... -> Setting -> General panel -> Console -> check Show timestamps, you can see the request-time easily

QRCode

When surfing the internet, you can click the blue earth icon on the right side of the location bar, then a QR code of the web page's URL will be generated. And you can double click the QR code, edit the content and get a new QR code. After this, use your mobile app to scan them! It's an easy way to share messages from PC to phone.

You can also add/edit your preferred google domain(or ip).
